awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research in IPY: Abrupt Environmental Change in the Larsen Ice Shelf System, a Multidisciplinary Approach - Marine and Quaternary Geosciences
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract

This award supports a research cruise to perform geologic studies in the area under and surrounding the former Larsen B ice shelf, on the Antarctic Peninsula. The ice shelf's disintegration in 2002 coupled with the unique marine geology of the area make it possible to understand the conditions leading to ice shelf collapse. Bellwethers of climate change that reflect both oceanographic and atmospheric conditions, ice shelves also hold back glacial flow in key areas of the polar regions. Their collapse results in glacial surging and could cause rapid rise in global sea levels. This project characterizes the Larsen ice shelf's history and conditions leading to its collapse by determining: 1) the size of the Larsen B during warmer climates and higher sea levels back to the Eemian interglacial, 125,000 years ago; 2) the configuration of the Antarctic Peninsula ice sheet during the LGM and its subsequent retreat; 3) the causes of the Larsen B's stability through the Holocene, during which other shelves have come and gone; 4) the controls on the dynamics of ice shelf margins, especially the roles of surface melting and oceanic processes, and 5) the changes in sediment flux, both biogenic and lithogenic, after large ice shelf breakup. 

 

The broader impacts include graduate and undergraduate education through research projects and workshops; outreach to the general public through a television documentary and websites, and international collaboration with scientists from Belgium, Spain, Argentina, Canada, Germany and the UK. The work also has important societal relevance. Improving our understanding of how ice shelves behave in a warming world will improve models of sea level rise.

 

The project is supported under NSF's International Polar Year (IPY) research emphasis area on "Understanding Environmental Change in Polar Regions".

por.por_cntn:
The Larsen Ice Shelf System Antarctic (LARISSA) program investigates the causes and effects of ice shelf collapse and glacier retreat in the Antarctic Peninsula (AP). We want to understand why AP ice shelves have been disintegrating catastrophically over the past 20+ years. Processes involved include warming air temperatures and surface melting of ice shelves, winds pushing warm water up against the Antarctic Peninsula and melting floating ice shelves from below, and processes that mechanically weaken the ice such as tidal flexing or rare events such as tsunamis. We want to determine the signature of each process so that we can recognize them in a sediment core or ice core, and extend the record of observations back through time. We want to understand what happens to the remaining land based ice, local ocean circulation, and marine ecosystems after ice shelves collapse.

During the grant period we conducted marine expeditions aboard the U.S. Antarctic Program Research Vessel Nathaniel B. Palmer in 2010 and 2012, and aboard the Korean Research Vessel Aaron in 2013 in collaboration with the Korean Polar Research Institute. We mapped the ocean floor and the subsurface using SONAR and seismology, deployed land-based meteorological instruments and marine based oceanographic instruments, and collected sediment cores, seafloor samples and videos of the seafloor, and water column samples. When combined, these materials and data allow us to study the modern geology, glaciology, oceanography, and biology within the Larsen Ice Shelf system (LIS; eastern AP) and the tidewater glaciers on the western AP. We apply these modern relationships and systems interactions to the interpretation of older records preserved in sediment cores (and in ice cores via collaboration with our partners at Ohio State University) in order to understand recent ice collapse events within a long-term context.

Montclair State University faculty and students were part of the LARISSA Marine Geology and Geophysics (MGG) team. We used marine sediments to track ice shelf and glacier behavior and stability back through time. This allowed us to understand natural cycles of variability and identify any new and unique events. We used lithic clasts, sediment geochemistry, and magnetic iron-bearing minerals to trace ice shelf and glacier behavior. We extracted sand and gravel grains from the sediment that were eroded by the ice and dropped into the ocean. If we know the local geology, we can use these grains as forensic tracers to match them back to their source or “provenance.” If we know where the grains came from and where they landed in the ocean, then we can determine the direction in which the ice flowed in the past. This glacial sediment is abundant during cold periods. In contrast, biologically produced (“biogenic”) material such as diatoms (marine phytoplankton) is more abundant during warm periods. This is a simple but powerful way to identify warm/cold alternations. In several of our study areas very little known about the local geology, which is hidden under the ice sheet. Therefore, we used bedrock samples from offshore islands and diamict samples from our cores to determine the composition of the hidden sub-ice bedrock. Glacial sediment in the inner and middle Barilari Bay sediment cores comes mainly from the Trinity Peninsula Group. The Andean Intrusive Suite supplies the majority of the magnetic iron-bearing minerals to the bay. The Andean Intrusive Suite, Jurassic Volcanics, and Trinity Peninsula Group each have unique iron mineral assemblages and magnetic behavior that allow the use of magnetic parameters as provenance tools.
